title: New sculpture given to Paris by Jeff Koons is dubbed 'pornographic and looking like marshmallows'
text:
A large tulip sculpture given to Paris as a tribute for the 2015 attacks has been mocked for looking 'pornographic' and 'like marshmallows'.

The Bouquet of Tulips sculpture, by US artist Jeff Koons, was unveiled on Friday near the Champs Elysées.

Done in his typical kitschy style, the sculpture has already received backlash from social media users.

The 40-foot high piece depicts a giant hand squeezing a bouquet of eleven colourful tulips, a flower that in some cultures symbolises love.

The Bouquet of Tulips sculpture, by US artist Jeff Koons, was unveiled on Friday near the Champs Elysées

Koons said he created the Bouquet of Tulips to show Americans' support and solidarity for the French people after the attacks in which a total of 130 people were killed.

He said: 'I did, as a citizen in New York, experience 9/11 and the depression that hung over the city. It really took years for the city to be able to come to life again.'

Koons said that 80 per cent of the proceeds from selling the copyright of the artwork will go to the victims' families. The remaining 20 per cent will be dedicated to its maintenance.

One Twitter user, Rosa Rosam, wrote that Parisians will now think that tulips are giant coloured marshmallows

Dominique Kielemoes, who lost her son in the attacks, said: 'The memory, commemorations, art, everything we do that can recall the memory of our loved ones is vital.'

Philosopher Yves Michaud described the sculpture as '11 coloured anuses mounted on stems' in L'Obs magazine.

One Twitter user, Rosa Rosam, wrote that Parisians will now think that tulips are giant coloured marshmallows.

Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo said that she was happy to unveil the work and called it a 'magnificent symbol of freedom and friendship', according to the BBC.
description: The Bouquet of Tulips was unveiled near the Champs Elyées on Friday. French philosopher Yves Michaud described the sculpture as '11 coloured anuses mounted on stems'.
